doc.title: July Optical Fiber & Optical Fiber Connector Tade Stats

passages.text: August 28, 2025 02:51 AM GMT
Wire & Cable | Japan
In July, exports of optical fiber connectors remained at record levels. Exports of optical fiber/cable were also brisk.

- Jul optical fiber/cable export value flat MoM, \(+64\%\) YoY; 2-digit YoY growth for a 12th straight month.- Jul optical fiber connector export value flat MoM, \(+63\%\) YoY. Exports were on par with previous month, remaining at record level.
Japan's MoF released July trade stats (revised data). Key data points for the optical fiber & connector industry were as follows.

Optical fiber/cable export value: ¥7.3bn (+64% YoY; +52% YoY 3-month avg; flat MoM), of which optical cables accounted for ¥4.0bn and optical fiber for ¥3.2bn. Apr- Jul 2025 optical fiber/cable export value was ¥27.8bn (+46% YoY).

Export value of key optical cable products (HS code 854470100) by customs office: Breakdown of total export value of ¥3.4bn: Tokyo Customs ¥1.7bn, Yokohama ¥1.6bn, Nagoya ¥0.013bn, Moji ¥0.024 bn, other ¥0.02bn. Exports to N. America & Western Europe from Tokyo/Yokohama Customs: Exports to N. America ¥2.5bn (+188% YoY; 3-month avg. +238% YoY; Tokyo ¥1.4bn and Yokohama ¥1.1bn). Exports to Western Europe ¥0.1bn (- 31% YoY; 3- mo avg. +39% YoY; breakdown: Tokyo ¥0.1bn, Yokohama ¥0.00054bn). Exports to N. America and W. Europe were both likely driven by shipments of ultra- high density cables. We think exports to N. America were mainly shipments to hyperscale data centers (HSDCs) by SEI & Fujikura and those to Western Europe were mainly to the BT Group by Fujikura.

Export value of optical fiber/optical fiber cable connectors (HS code 85367000): Total export value of ¥3.5bn (+63% YoY; 3- mo avg. +64% YoY; flat MoM). Exports were on par with previous month, remaining at a record level. Total figure breaks down to Tokyo Customs ¥3.1bn, Nagoya ¥0.18bn, Osaka ¥0.18bn, other ¥0.0076bn. Tokyo Customs figure breaks down to N. America ¥1.5bn (+34% YoY; 3- mo avg. +34% YoY; - 18% MoM), Asia ¥1.5bn, Western Europe ¥0.05bn, other ¥0.025bn. We think exports to N. America were driven by Fujikura shipments to HSDCs. We attribute buoyant demand to cross- connectivity of AI servers, which requires several times more connectors than usual. Exports to Asia also grew significantly, which is consistent with Fujikura's comments after 1Q results.
MORGAN STANLEY MUFG SECURITIES CO., LTD. +
WIRE & CABLE Japan Industry View

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

\(+ =\) Analysts employed by non- U.S. affiliates are not registered with FINRA, may not be associated persons of the member and may not be subject to FINRA restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst account.

Splicer exports (HS code 851580000): Export value was Kumamoto customs \(¥0.68bn(+29\% YoY,3 - mo\) avg. \(+0.47\%\) YoY, \(+17\%\) MoM) and Yokohama customs \(¥0.09bn\) (- 46% YoY, 3- mo avg. \(+86\%\) YoY, \(+46\%\) MoM). We think shipments out of Kumamoto were Fujikura's while those out of Yokohama were Sumitomo Electric's. Note that the HS code includes arc welders and other equipment, so we do not look at the total export value.
Power cable exports (1kV+, HS code 854460100): Total export value of \(¥0.86bn\)

Implications for the wire & cable industry: In July, shipments of optical fiber/cable and fiber cable connectors were brisk. The strong figures affirm the strength of demand for data center applications and bode well for the wire & cable industry in our view. That said, outcomes naturally fluctuate widely depending on the month, and single- month data is not a sufficient catalyst on its own. Developments thus warrant monitoring.

Key optical fiber/cable manufacturing sites in Japan include SEI's Yokohama Works, Fujikura's Sakura Works, Furukawa Electric's Mie Works, and OCC (submarine optical cables in Kitakyushu). We think Tokyo Customs and Yokohama Customs reflect shipment trends at SEI & Fujikura, particularly shipments of ultra- high density cables to N. America & Western Europe. Meanwhile, Moji Customs likely reflects shipments at OCC (NEC/SEI JV, sole maker of submarine optical cables in Japan); SEI supplies submarine optical fibers to OCC. We think Nagoya Customs reflects shipments from Furukawa's Mie Works, but with US subsidiary OFS handling most of its business, exports from domestic sites are likely limited.

Source: MoF, Morgan Stanley Research

Morgan Stanley uses a relative rating system using terms such as Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated or Underweight (see definitions below). Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold and sell. In addition, since Morgan Stanley Research contains more complete information concerning the analyst's views, investors should carefully read Morgan Stanley Research, in its entirety, and not infer the contents from the rating alone. In any case, ratings (or research) should not be used or relied upon as investment advice. (as of July 31, 2025)

The Stock Ratings described below apply to Morgan Stanley's Fundamental Equity Research and do not apply to Debt Research produced by the Firm. For disclosure purposes only (in accordance with FINRA requirements), we include the category headings of Buy, Hold, and Sell alongside our ratings of Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight. Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold, and sell but represent recommended relative weightings (see definitions below). To satisfy regulatory requirements, we correspond Overweight, our most positive stock rating, with a buy recommendation; we correspond Equal- weight and Not- Rated to hold and Underweight to sell recommendations, respectively.

Data include common stock and ADRs currently assigned ratings. Investment Banking Clients are companies from whom Morgan Stanley received investment banking compensation in the last 12 months. Due to rounding off of decimals, the percentages provided in the % of total' column may not add up to exactly 100 percent.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia -relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
